an10.27:4.1: At one time the Buddha was staying near Sāvatthī, in Jeta’s Grove, Anāthapiṇḍika’s monastery.
an10.27:4.2: Then several mendicants got dressed in the morning and, taking their bowls and robes, entered Sāvatthī for alms.
an10.27:4.4: “It’s too early to wander for alms in Sāvatthī.
an10.27:4.5: Why don’t we go to the monastery of the wanderers who follow other paths?”
an10.27:5.1: Then they went to the monastery of the wanderers who follow other paths,
an10.27:5.2: and exchanged greetings with the wanderers there.
an10.27:5.3: When the greetings and polite conversation were over, they sat down to one side.
an10.27:6.1: “Reverends, the ascetic Gotama teaches his disciples like this:
an10.27:6.2: ‘Please, mendicants, have insight into all things. Live having had insight into all things.’
an10.27:6.4: ‘Please, reverends, have insight into all things. Live having had insight into all things.’
an10.27:6.5: What, then, is the difference between the ascetic Gotama’s teaching and instruction and ours?”
an10.27:7.1: Those mendicants neither approved nor dismissed that statement of the wanderers who follow other paths.
an10.27:7.2: They got up from their seat, thinking:
an10.27:7.3: “We will learn the meaning of this statement from the Buddha himself.”
an10.27:8.1: Then, after the meal, when they returned from alms-round, they went up to the Buddha,
an10.27:8.2: bowed, sat down to one side,
an10.27:8.3: and told him what had happened.
an10.27:12.1: “Mendicants, when wanderers who follow other paths say this, you should say to them:
an10.27:12.2: ‘One thing: question, summary, and answer. Two … three … four … five … six … seven … eight … nine … ten things: question, summary, and answer.’
an10.27:12.3: Questioned like this, the wanderers who follow other paths would be stumped, and, in addition, would get frustrated.
an10.27:12.5: Because they’re out of their element.
an10.27:12.6: I don’t see anyone in this world—with its gods, Māras, and Brahmās, this population with its ascetics and brahmins, its gods and humans—who could provide a satisfying answer to these questions except for the Realized One or his disciple or someone who has heard it from them.
an10.27:13.1: ‘One thing: question, summary, and answer.’ That’s what I said,
an10.27:13.2: but why did I say it?
an10.27:13.3: Becoming completely disillusioned with one thing—completely disenchanted and freed from it, seeing its limits and fully comprehending its meaning—a mendicant makes an end of suffering in this very life.
an10.27:13.5: ‘All sentient beings are sustained by food.’
an10.27:13.6: Becoming completely disillusioned, disenchanted, and freed with this one thing, seeing its limits and fully comprehending its meaning, a mendicant makes an end of suffering in this very life.
an10.27:13.7: ‘One thing: question, summary, and answer.’ That’s what I said, and this is why I said it.
an10.27:21.5: The nine abodes of sentient beings. …
an10.27:22.1: ‘Ten things: question, summary, and answer.’ That’s what I said,
an10.27:22.2: but why did I say it?
an10.27:22.3: Becoming completely disillusioned with ten things—completely disenchanted and freed from them, seeing their limits and fully comprehending their meaning—a mendicant makes an end of suffering in this very life.
an10.27:22.5: The ten ways of performing unwholesome deeds.
an10.27:22.6: Becoming completely disillusioned with these ten things—completely disenchanted and freed from them, seeing their limits and fully comprehending their meaning—a mendicant makes an end of suffering in this very life.
an10.27:22.7: ‘Ten things: question, summary, and answer.’ That’s what I said, and this is why I said it.”
